captions.text:
Hi I'm Alois Rosario and I'm Jeff Plumb from
PingSkills.com and today we are going to talk
about the forehand topspin against block.

SO let us have a look at the 3 basic things
we need to consider with the forehand topspin
stroke.

Firstly let us consider our leg position.
We need to have our feet nice and wide apart,

you can either be quite square on to the table
or because it is more of an aggressive stroke

you can turn a little bit more towards your
forehand side.

The second thing we need to consider is your
start position. You are starting with your

bat fairly flat you can turn it over, we will
talk about that a little bit later, but your

starting position needs to be down and around
knee high or between your hip and you knee.

The third thing to consider is we need to
make a brushing contact and then finish with

your bat up nice and high above your head
with a 90 degree angle here and a 90 degree
angle here.

When you are starting out you can start with
a nice flat bat like Jeff is doing here. As

you can see he is still generating topspin
on the ball by starting low and finishing

high and he is brushing up the back of the
ball. But there will be a limit to how fast

you can hit this type of stroke with such
a lifting action. Eventually the ball has

to go off the end of the end of the table.
So how do we hit the ball faster? There are

two things, one we need to turn our bat forward
and we need to get our stroke a little bit

more forward as well. So rather than the very
lifting stroke now we are starting a little

bit further back with the angle down and coming
forward.

If you have found this lesson on the forehand
topspin useful, go to PingSkills.com where

you will find lots more information about
the strokes of Table Tennis.

title: Table Tennis Forehand Topspin Against Block

comments.text: Do I lock my wrist when I do this?﻿
comments.author: ItsCrystal

comments.text:
Hi +ItsCrystal,

You don't lock your wrist, just keep it fairly relaxed and you'll naturally 
get some movement which can help your stroke. When you are learning the 
stroke though don't focus on the wrist, instead really concentrate on 
getting the start and finish positions correct.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text: how can i spin the chop ball from my opponent ??﻿
comments.author: muhammad fahmi

comments.text:
Hi +muhammad fahmi,

You can push the ball back or topspin it back. Go to our website and look 
at the Lessons page, and then the strokes & techniques section. There you 
can see the backhand push lesson, and the forehand topspin against backspin 
lessons. Watch these and they will help you out. Good luck!
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text:
I'm just curious Pingskills regarding the finishing position of the loop 
and forehand topspin. At the end of the stroke does the bat angle have to 
be at the side of your head or tilted at your head?﻿
comments.author: James Tse

comments.text:
Hi +James Tse,

I'm not entirely sure what you mean by the question. You want to keep the 
bat angle consistent throughout the entire stroke. See if you can watch the 
video again and see the finish position and see if it answers your 
question. If I haven't answered your question then please let me know and 
I'll try again.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text:
Why doesn't he extend his arm much? Wouldn't that give the ball more power 
and spin?﻿
comments.author: DaJaguar

comments.text: +DaJaguar You're welcome. I'm glad you are finding the videos helpful.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text:
+PingSkills Thanks for the explanation! I'm pretty new to this game but I 
find your videos pretty useful! :)
comments.author: DaJaguar

comments.text:
Hi +DaJaguar, you can certainly extend your arm more. Some players like to 
keep the stroke a bit shorter as they feel it gives them more control and 
with the speed of the rackets and by using the twisting motion, your legs, 
wrist, you can still generate a lot of power. People tend to categorise 
these two styles as the Chinese loop (bigger arm motion) and the European 
loop (smaller arm motion).
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text:
I always favour my backhand block over my forehand which allows my opponent 
to go on the attack and get the point most of the time. How do I stop doing 
that and actually play my forehand more? ﻿
comments.author: vijay sekar

comments.text:
Hi +vijay sekar,

It really comes down to practice. See if you can get a training partner to 
loop the ball to your forehand over and over. The more you practice it the 
more comfortable you will be with it. This is to practice the block which 
you mentioned in your comments. For an attacking stroke, like we show in 
the video, you can loop the ball and have your partner block it back to you.
comments.author: PingSkills

luck!

comments.text:
Seems you do this stroke without using the swing of your arm, but instead 
you use shoulder/body rotation? I make more use of the swing of my arm 
rather than shoulder rotation, Should I change that? Does it make me more 
consistent if i go for shoulder body rotation rather than arm rotation?
comments.author: 3isico

comments.text: You're welcome.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text: Try to watch the ball as closely as possible. This is really important.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text:
Correct. A loop is a shot with lots of topspin that causes the ball to dip. 
It is also refered to as a topspin stroke.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text:
It's all about the brushing action. Against backspin your stroke can be 
more vertical. Make a fine brushing contact and as it is a fine contact you 
can move your bat through quite fast. You can also ask questions on our 
website under the ask the coach section. There we have a lot more room to 
answer your questions.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text: sir how do i get more topspin on the ball? escpecially against the backspin?
comments.author: Detherocable

comments.text:
What's the difference between the european style loop and chinese style 
loop? And which one is shown in the video?
comments.author: MikvasEye

comments.text:
miss your speeding up forearm..... drafting and fast buckling at the ball 
touch - sorry for this scary englisch... i don't know the technical terms 
in englisch...
comments.author: Marcel Kaufmann

comments.text:
The topspin is an extension of the counterhit. You put more topspin on the 
ball which causes the ball to dip and allows you to hit the ball harder and 
still get it on the table.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text: Nice tutorial. Thanks for the tips guys ;)
comments.author: Uberpong

comments.text:
Great questions. The best place for in depth conversations is on our 
website under the ask the coach section. There we are not limited by the 
length of the comment box. If you post a question about this there Alois 
will answer it for you. The shoulder rotations are an important part of the 
stroke when you are trying to generate more power as to are the legs, the 
arm and even the wrist. All of this will help you get the bat moving 
through faster.
comments.author: PingSkills

comments.text:
Thanks, I've been told shoulder rotation movements are quite slow to recoil 
(compared to elbow rotation), are they promoted in this vid because the 
block is a rather slow ball ? I guess we wouldnt have time to make a full 
elbow swing against a more agressive couter ball,would we ?
comments.author: manu de hanoi

comments.text:
Not necessarily starting at 90/90. This is the finish position. Some 
players like to start with the arm quite straight and others prefer it more 
bent. Find what feels comfortable for you.
